Award.AwardTitle: Integrated Knowledge-Based Experiences for First-Year Biology and Chemistry Laboratories

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Education and Human Resources

Award.AbstractNarration: This project is designing an integrated curriculum between general chemistry and biology laboratories unified by writing to create a common theme of STEM inquiry for first-year students. It investigates how a cohesive first-year science and writing curriculum can help students improve their capacities to synthesize knowledge across disciplines, build contextual frameworks for assimilating new knowledge, develop proficiency in laboratory and writing skills, and improve attitudes toward science and communication. Project goals are met through the development and assessment of integrated biology and chemistry laboratories, writing modules relating to skills development (e.g., microscopy and other lab techniques, data management and analysis, source analysis and integration, scientific writing, peer review, oral communication), and investigation of biochemical principles and processes (e.g., chemical nature of biomolecules, oxidation-reduction and enzymatic reactions, light absorption by pigments, chemical effects on cellular structures). This model for lower-division interdisciplinary study is being developed to be broadly transferable to a wide variety of post-secondary institutions, and contributes to an emerging paradigm of coordinated scientific teaching among current and future faculty and associated teaching assistants. The laboratory modules and integration pedagogy are peer-reviewed, made publicly available, and disseminated to networks of STEM and writing educators.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The primary goals of this project were to (1) improve students’ ability to learn and apply concepts across introductory courses in biology and chemistry disciplines, (2) build a frameworks for synthesizing and assimilating new knowledge, (3) develop proficiency in laboratory and writing skills, and (4) improve student attitudes toward science. 

The project enrolled 3 separate cohorts of first-year college students with approximately 20 students per group. The project investigators developed integrated laboratory modules by transforming common experiments in each discipline or developing new modules that emphasize the project goals. This approach contrasted to the traditional approach where we provide siloed content in core disciplines, especially in large first-year introductory courses. The new course experience built upon existing separate lecture courses while integrating the laboratories into a new engaging laboratory and seminar experience. Concepts and content from biology and chemistry labs were further integrated into a first-year writing course to exemplify the parallel structure of sourcing and developing arguments in science and in writing.

The curriculum paid special attention to synergistic and real-world problems as well as accessible lab and field experiences. Students were able relate personal experiences and motivations to the experimental work in the field and the lab. Students applied skills and concepts between disciplinary fields and results suggest that they are better able to synthesize connections between them. The students developed proficiency in written and oral communication, a vital skill for scientists who need to convey the implications of their work and generate a better-informed citizenry. Beyond writing lab reports, students also developed and delivered a poster on an interdiscplinary lab as well as authored and illustrated a children's book with interdisciplinary science themes. A network of young scientists emerged with a greater understanding of how science is conducted and the nature of the scientific process. 

Results indicate there is a strong cohort affect among students as they made significant and lasting personal relationships during the one-year project experience. Because only a small number of students were involved and they self-selected at random, academic achievement was difficult to model and control. We did, however, see greater changes in academic improvement compared to control group. They also showed some improvements in traditional writing skills in addition to improvements in writing for context and audience.

Experiences and results were discussed with practitioners at national conferences as well as with state and local partners. The project resulted in the development of several new laboratory exercises, which are currently being prepared for publication.
